content.title: Varicose Veins
content.definition: Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous superficial veins >3mm in diameter, resulting from venous valvular incompetence and venous hypertension, most commonly affecting the great and small saphenous systems.

pathophysiology.primary_valvular_incompetence: Most common - valve cusp damage or annular dilation
pathophysiology.venous_hypertension: Sustained ambulatory venous pressure leads to progression

clinical_presentation.symptom_pattern: Worse with standing, end of day; better with elevation, walking

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Gold standard - maps reflux, excludes DVT
diagnosis.reflux_criteria: >0.5 seconds for superficial, >1 second for deep

ceap_classification.C0: No visible or palpable venous disease

treatment.conservative: Compression stockings, leg elevation, exercise, weight loss
treatment.thermal_ablation: Endovenous laser (EVLA) or radiofrequency (RFA) - first-line for GSV/SSV
treatment.surgery: High ligation and stripping (less common now), phlebectomy

learning_objectives: Define varicose veins and distinguish from other venous abnormalities
Describe CEAP classification for chronic venous disease
Outline diagnostic approach including duplex ultrasound findings
Compare modern treatment options for varicose veins
clinical_pearls: Always perform duplex before treatment to map reflux patterns and exclude DVT
Endovenous ablation has largely replaced surgical stripping
Reflux >0.5 seconds is abnormal for superficial veins
Compression therapy is cornerstone of conservative management
pedagogical.board_yield: HIGH - extremely common topic on vascular boards
